Questions.QuestionString: 1. How many floor path lights can you fly with unserviceable?. (Level 1)
2. In the CWS system, the caution light is coloured. (Level 1)
3. What inert gas is used in a typical strobe light?. (Level 1)
4. Tritium Gas is used in a. (Level 1)
5. The visible angle of a white tail navigation light is. (Level 1)
6. Wing navigation lights must be visible through which angle?. (Level 1)
7. Escape route lighting must not have more than. (Level 1)
8. A fluorescent tube contains. (Level 2)
Answers: A. orange coatings, rare gases and mercury vapour.
B. phosphor coatings, rare gases and mercury vapour.
C. iodine coatings and rare gases.

Questions.QuestionString: 9. Cockpit dome lighting is provided by the. (Level 2)
Answers: A. battery bus and ground services bus.

Questions.QuestionString: 10. Cargo bay lights on a modern aircraft are supplied by. (Level 2)

11. What will happen if the Master Dim and test switch is switched to the on position?.
(Level 2)
Answers: A. Rectangular indicator lights will illuminate.

Questions.QuestionString: 12. What is the arc of a landing light?. (Level 1)

13. In what position should the selector switch be for a standby and emergency lighting
system during flight. (Level 2)
14. A rotating beacon must have a minimum light rating of. (Level 2)

15. Before touching or disconnecting a strobe light head, a time period must elapse to avoid
electrical shock or burning. That time period is at least. (Level 2)
16. Captain and First Officer's 'Dome' lights can be dimmed. (Level 2)
Answers: A. individually - they are wired in parallel.
B. together - they are wired in series.
C. First Officer's only in emergency mode.

Questions.QuestionString: 17. On a CWS, which has the highest priority?. (Level 2)

18. Floor proximity lighting is a mandatory requirement and each light should be spaced.
(Level 2)

19. A strobe light is a light unit that takes form of glass tube filled with which gas and its
light colour is what?. (Level 2)
20. The aircraft has a partial failure of its emergency lighting system. (Level 2)
Answers: A. continue with reduced passenger load.
B. ferry flight to main base for rectification.

Questions.QuestionString: 21. Navigation lights are supplied by the following circuit. (Level 2)
22. Automatic no smoking sign will illuminate. (Level 2)
Answers: B. when landing gear doors are not closed.
C. when landing gear is up.

Questions.QuestionString: 23. The visible angle of a white tail navigation light is. (Level 1)

24. In what position should the selector switch be for a standby and emergency lighting
system during flight. (Level 2)
25. A rotating beacon must have a minimum light rating of. (Level 2)

26. Before touching or disconnecting a strobe light head, a time period must elapse to avoid
electrical shock or burning. That time period is at least. (Level 2)

27. Floor proximity lighting is a mandatory requirement and each light should be spaced.
(Level 2)
28. With aircraft lights - which of the following is true?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. Starboard light green, port light red, tail light white.
B. Starboard light red, port light green, tail light Red.
C. Starboard light red, port light green, tail light White.

Questions.QuestionString: 29. Emergency floor lighting system is inoperative, then. (Level 3)
Answers: A. the aircraft is not allowed to fly until repaired.
B. the aircraft is allowed to fly in daylight conditions only.
C. the aircraft is allowed to fly empty to a main base.

Questions.QuestionString: 30. A white steady light is required. (Level 3)
Answers: A. of at least 3 candelas, at the rear of the aircraft 70 degrees either side of dead astern.
B. of at least 3 lumens, at the rear of the aircraft 110 degrees either side of dead astern.
C. of at least 3 candelas, at the rear of the aircraft 110 degrees either side of dead astern.

Questions.QuestionString: 31. How are passenger reading lights normally tested?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. Each one is switched on individually at passenger panel.
B. By using a READ LIGHT TEST switch at any passenger panel.
C. By using a READ LIGHT TEST switch on the cabin attendant panel.

Questions.QuestionString:
32. The emergency lighting system must be designed so that after any single transverse
vertical separation of the fuselage during crash landing the maximum amount of emergency
lighting that fails is. (Level 3)
33. Service lights include. (Level 3)
Answers: A. refuelling lights, engine scanning lights, logo lights.
B. avionics bay lights, engine scanning lights, baggage compartment lights.
C. baggage compartment lights, avionics bay lights, refuelling lights.

Questions.QuestionString: 34. Wing navigation lights must be visible through which angle?. (Level 1)
35. If the 'blow-back' device on a landing lamp operates, how is it reset?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. The linkage must be repositioned and latched when the aircraft is on the ground.
C. It cannot. The unit must be replaced because of the high stress loads experienced.

Questions.QuestionString:
36. The rear light of an aircraft must be white and, in addition, must show through an
inclusive angle of. (Level 3)
Answers: A. 110 degrees and be 5 candelas minimum.
B. 110 degrees and be 40 candelas minimum.
C. 140 degrees and be 3 candelas minimum.

Questions.QuestionString: 37. Self-illuminating signs. (Level 3)
Answers: A. are instantly seen in dark areas by persons who are not dark adapted.
B. require a period of daylight, or intense artificial light to operate.
C. are self powered and contain phosphor and helium gas.

Questions.QuestionString: 38. When an annunciator light is selected to 'DIM', the resistor is in. (Level 3)
Answers: A. parallel with the light and the transistor is not conducting.
B. series with the light and the transistor is not conducting.
C. series with the light and the transistor is conducting.

Questions.QuestionString: 39. Storm lights are usually fluorescent lights that are switched on. (Level 3)
Answers: A. because lightning has less effect on fluorescent lamp units.
B. and the glare-shield lights are automatically dimmed.
C. to reduce the effect of lightning on the pilot's sight.

Questions.QuestionString:
40. The emergency lighting system must be designed so that after any single transverse
vertical separation of the fuselage during crash landing the maximum amount of emergency
lighting that fails is. (Level 3)
41. Service lights include. (Level 3)
Answers: A. fuelling lights, engine scanning lights, logo lights.
B. avionics bay lights, engine scanning lights, baggage compartment lights.
C. baggage compartment lights, avionics bay lights, refuelling lights.

Questions.QuestionString: 42. If the 'blow-back' device on a landing lamp operates, how is it reset?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. The linkage must be repositioned and latched when the aircraft is on the air.
C. It cannot. The unit must be replaced because of the high stress loads experienced.

Questions.QuestionString:
43. The rear light of an aircraft must be white and, in addition, must show through an
inclusive angle of. (Level 3)
Answers: A. 180 degrees and be 5 candelas minimum.
B. 110 degrees and be 40 candelas minimum.
C. 140 degrees and be 3 candelas minimum.

46. How many emergency lights are allowed to be inoperative?. (Level 1)

50. Lux is measured in

53. When replacing halogen lamps, we must
Answers: A. Lub the cover of the light

Questions.QuestionString: 54. Before applying maintenance for HID lamp, we should wait

55. In what position should the selector switch be for a standby and emergency lighting
system during flight.
56. How many methods can produce LEDs color?
57. Which of the following descriptions of the Landing lights is correct?
Answers: A. Support flight crew to see the area ahead of the aircraft during the final stages of landing.

B. The landing lights provide a very intense, narrow beam of white light which is normally
directed at a fixed angle in relation to the aircraft

C. Support flight crew to see the area ahead of the aircraft during the final stages of landing
and provide a very intense, narrow beam of white light which is normally directed at a fixed
angle in relation to the aircraft.

Questions.QuestionString: 58. What is the typical power rating of taxi light?
59. What is the purpose of aircraft external lighting?
Answers:
A. Allow the aircraft to be clearly visible from the outside during operations in the air and on
the ground
B. For everyone outside the Aircraft can see the Aircraft

C. Providing the crew and Passengers with a sufficient view of the outside world to operate
safely.

Questions.QuestionString: 60. Navigation lighting under JAR part 23 and 25 par 1385 and 1397 regulations has to
Answers: A. RED = Left wing tip; GREEN = Right wing tip; WHITE = The tail light
B. RED = Right wing tip; GREEN = Left wing tip; WHITE = The tail light
C. RED = Left wing tip; GREEN = The tail light; WHITE = Left wing tip

Questions.QuestionString: 61. Emergency floor lighting system is inoperative, then
Answers: A. The aircraft is allowed to fly empty to a main base
B. The aircraft is allowed to fly in daylight conditions only
C. It's fine for pilot to keep flying, repair later

Questions.QuestionString: 62. Which of the following lights belongs to the cockpit?
Answers:
A. Flood light, storm lighting, pedestal light, work lamps, map light, emergency light, smoke
light
B. Flood light, storm lighting, pedestal light, work lamps, map light, console light
C. Reading light, Return to seat light, pedestal light, work lamps, map light, console light

Questions.QuestionString: 63. The power supply for the landing lights is normally?
Answers: A. 24v DC and the power rating will be around 600 watts.
B. 28v AC or DC and the power rating will be around 600 watts.
C. 115V AC and the power rating will be around 600 watts.

Questions.QuestionString: 64. Which of the following descriptions of the internal lights is correct?
Answers: A. The internal lights must enable the flight crew to operate the aircraft safely

B. The cabin crew to carry out their duties effectively and allow adequate lighting for the
passengers to be comfortable in normal aircraft operation.

C. The internal lights must enable the flight crew to operate the aircraft safely, the cabin crew
to carry out their duties effectively and allow adequate lighting for the passengers to be
comfortable in normal aircraft operation.
